Problem:
Consider the analytical solution of the heat equation \\( u_t = ku_{xx} \\) under initial conditions that can be represented as a Fourier transform. An operation \\( f(u) = u + e^{i\\omega_0 x} \\) is introduced, where \\( \\omega_0 \\) is a constant frequency.

If an additional perturbation represented by \\( g(u) = u + e^{-i\\alpha x} \\) (where \\( \\alpha \\) is another constant frequency) is introduced as an intervention at a later time \\( t_1 \\), will the temperature profile \\( u(x,T) \\) for T > t_1 depend only on the initial perturbation and not on the nature of \\( \\omega_0 \\) or \\( \\alpha \\)?
Explanation: The introduction of \\( g(u) \\) adds another independent sinusoidal perturbation to the evolving solution. The final state \\( u(x,T) \\) depends not only on the original perturbation \\( \\omega_0 \\) from \\( f(u) \\) but also on the new perturbation \\( \\alpha \\) introduced at \\( t_1 \\). Each sinusoidal component will evolve under the heat equation, affecting the overall temperature distribution at any given time thereafter.
